workbooks/baremetal.yaml.message:
For some reason I had expected the workflow to register all nodes, then introspect all nodes and then provide all nodes. In three steps. Instead you are taking one node through each step individually.

The main issue is that the messages sent by the introspect workflow assume it has all of the nodes. For example:


message: <% 'Retrying {0} nodes that failed introspection. Attempt {1} of {2} '.format($.failed_introspection.len(), $.introspection_attempt, $.max_retry_attempts + 1) %>
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/master/workbooks/baremetal.yaml#L592

If you are registering 10 nodes (for example) and 5 have problems. You will get output like this...

Retrying 1 nodes that failed introspection. Attempt 1 of 2
Retrying 1 nodes that failed introspection. Attempt 1 of 2
Retrying 1 nodes that failed introspection. Attempt 1 of 2
Retrying 1 nodes that failed introspection. Attempt 1 of 2
Retrying 1 nodes that failed introspection. Attempt 1 of 2

When if it were passed all the nodes you would get this...

Retrying 5 nodes that failed introspection. Attempt 1 of 2

The first version of this patchset does that (register all nodes, introspect all nodes, provide all nodes). The problem with that approach is that the error handling - we want to be able to let single nodes fail while others go on to finish the whole process successfully. I see the issue you are raising with output being confusing with this approach, but I'm not sure how to address that. I'll think about it some more.

You can remove the need for the register_failed task by using publish-on-error and merging it into this one.

publish-on-error:
  status: FAILED
  message: <% task(register).result %>
on-error: send_message

I only recently learned this - and we don't do it in many places (but probably should). This isn't an essential change, but I want to try and clean up the other places we can do this over time.
Cool tip, I didn't know about this. I'll incorporate it in the next version.

I think this will fail as it expects a list.

    <% [$.registered_node.uuid] %>
regestered_node is actually a list with one element (see line 1248), so this works. I guess I should just leave the variable name register_nodes to avoid this confusion.
Oops, these 2 lines are a remnant of manual testing - I'll remove them in the next version.

tripleo_common/utils/ansible.py.message:
Mathieu,
Maybe you could be interested by 
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669697/9/tripleoclient/utils.py

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I understand the clarity of direct execution is better, but doing this kinda goes in opposite direction of ever achieving CLI-UI parity. I think some time ago TripleO devs sorta agreed that whenever possible, we'll drive things through Mistral instead of implementing CLI-specific and UI-specific forks of logic.

Also it puts upgrades further from how normal deployment with config-download works. AFAIK normal deployment still goes through Mistral, no?

I wonder if we can do something about the readability/debuggability without sacrificing the above...

Thank you Jiri for the feedback.

Yes the normal Overcloud deployment still goes with mistral, but the Standalone does not.
That one of the reasons why I proposed this approach, more oriented to what the standalone deployment is doing.

Another reason is, the initial deployment is doing a heat stack create + ansible configuration run, whereas Upgrade is doing this in two separate steps, meaning that the steps 2 (Ansible nodes upgrade) is only a simple Ansible call.
That's why I'm thinking that reducing the layer here is good for user experience since the usage of mistral is more a "stick to the design" than a "real useful layer".

And the last reason is that the UI doesn't support the Upgrade (and iirc, won't support at all since it's a very critical steps of the life cycle of TripleO).

So those 3 reasons make me proposed this very simple approach for the nodes upgrade/update

There is another way in the middle of this one and current one in the product. I will make a proposal review but it will still use mistral to trigger Ansible, just reduce the number of zaqar queue and the way we are consuming it.

Nah, it needs to support creating/updating MATCH blocks for this service e.g https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/base/nova/migration/target.pp#L73

this is back to one of my earlier concerns that this service now depends on a deprecated service.

I think the steps here should be to:
- add the new sshd template
- update nova-migration-target-container-puppet to use the new template
- deprecate the old sshd template

That can happen in a single patch or multiple patches, but we can't mark the old sshd template deprecated without first updating this service as well.

nova-migration-target-container-puppet is a containerised sshd, sshd-baremetal-ansible is the host sshd.

AFAIK we don't currently have a deploy step to generate container config using ansible roles. Until/unless we do we cannot switch nova-migration-target-container-puppet to ansible.

Also nova-migration-target-container-puppet requires more advanced sshd config, e.g Match blocks, which isn't currently supported in the tripleo-sshd ansible role.

I think the only options for now are to not deprecated the puppet sshd service, or go ahead and deprecated it but duplicate the config_settings here.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: note that v1/device_label.py may also perform a device_label_destroy() ... please confirm there should be no issue if these operations performed concurrently.
Added another check for device label that is not associated with any hardware. These entries cannot be deleted using host-device-label-remove command.

If we're re-applying a root-key image or a key-revocation image that has already been written to the hardware, or re-applying the functional image that is currently on the device, then we don't actually need or want to do this because the hardware is already in the desired state.

(In the case of the root-key and key-revocation images the duplicate image write might actually fail...I'd have to double-check.)
Modified process_device_image_apply to determine whether the states need to be set to pending and return True if it is.

I don't think this is entirely correct.  For example, if we "apply" a functional image, then write it out to hardware, then immediately "apply" the same functional image again via a different label it wouldn't make sense to set it to pending or to write it out to hardware again because the hardware is already in the desired state.

"applying" an image is a way of expressing the desired end state, not a way of expressing an action.  So if we're already at the desired end state, there's nothing to do.
Will this properly handle the case where we wrote functional image A to the hardware, then wrote image B, and now are trying to write image A again?
Teresa says that in this scenario when we applied image B it would delete the device_image_state table entries for image A, so we should be okay here.

It's not just each parameter on its own line though. It's the parameter plus the type hint for that parameter. This becomes more obvious with more complex your signatures get. As an example, I personally find this:

    def _notify_about_instance_usage(
        self,
        context: nova_context.RequestContext,
        instance: 'objects.Instance',
        event_suffix: str,
        network_info: ty.Dict[str, ty.Any] = None,
        extra_usage_info: ty.Dict[str, ty.Any] = None,
        fault: Exception = None,
    ):
        pass

much easier to grok than this:

    def _notify_about_instance_usage(
        self, context: nova_context.RequestContext, instance: 'objects.Instance',
        event_suffix: str, network_info: ty.Dict[str, ty.Any] = None,
        extra_usage_info: ty.Dict[str, ty.Any] = None, fault: Exception = None):
        pass

I mean, you can parse the first one pretty easily without syntax highlighting. I think it's just easier say always do things this way rather than trying to guess. You might end up wasting a bit of vertical space every now and then, but it's simpler and better in the general case.

(and yes, I know you'd suggest indenting the parameters in the second example further, but if you do that then you basically end up having to place everything on a separate line anyway)

Just wondering about the tl;dr on the type annotations -- I skimmed the comments on this review and from what I can tell, being that python itself does not enforce type annotations [1], it sounds like we intend these to be enforced instead by mypy. And we run mypy during our pep8 job?

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/dbe326158c6847fa8b2e584b60219ad7/log/job-output.txt#822

I see invocation of the mypywrap.sh script but it wasn't clear to me what is the output from mypy. Is this it? "Success: no issues found in 6 source files"

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html

> Just wondering about the tl;dr on the type annotations -- I skimmed
 > the comments on this review and from what I can tell, being that
 > python itself does not enforce type annotations [1], it sounds like
 > we intend these to be enforced instead by mypy. And we run mypy
 > during our pep8 job?

Correct. It's run via the 'pep8' target and can also be run separately via the 'mypy' tox target. FWIW, it is possible to get runtime type checking using something like typeguard [1] but we're nowhere near ready for that, even if we wanted to use it (which I'm not sure we do).

 > https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/dbe326158c6847fa8b2e584b60219ad7/log/job-output.txt#822
 > 
 > I see invocation of the mypywrap.sh script but it wasn't clear to
 > me what is the output from mypy. Is this it? "Success: no issues
 > found in 6 source files"
 > 
 > [1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html

mypy can and is being run in "incremental" mode, whereby type hints don't have to be complete and mypy will attempt to guess the various types (typically anything but the most trivial stuff will just resolve to 'ty.Any'). Even with incremental mode enabled though, nova has a lot of mypy-incompatible code that has to be addressed. For example, this could include things changing a variable 'foo' from e.g. a list to a set mid-function. We want to avoid a *huge* refactoring change to fix all those issues, so we've decided to introduce things gradually. To that end, the 'mypy-files.txt' file at the root of the repo lists files that we have introduced some level of type hints for (or at least resolved the most obvious incompatibilities for). There's nothing stopping you adding type hints to any file, but if a file isn't in that list then the type hints aren't validated and are essentially comments. For example, Sean has (or should have) added this particular file to that list in this change. However, you'll also note there are type hints in some of the test files. Those aren't aren't listed in the 'mypy-files.txt' file which means they're not currently checked, and will likely never be checked, because we use both duck typing and mocking _very_ liberally in our tests.

[1] https://github.com/agronholm/typeguard

It is only possible if the ip_allocation of the port is set to 'deferred'. And also this case makes the assumption that a neutron network has segment on _every_ compute host in the system so the scheduler free to choose any host.
Done

Migration is the most prominent case I agree. However there are multiple other cases for simple boot as well:

* there could be compute hosts without network segment from a given neutron network the port uses. Then the scheduler cannot select the hosts without segment
* there could be a port with ip_allocation=immediate, then neutron assigns a segment at port create and therefore the scheduler can only select a host that is in the selected segment.
* there could be boot with network. Then nova creates the port after the scheduling. In this case nova needs to make sure it creates the  port with ip_allocation=deferred settings.
Done

I think neutron creates the host aggregate in nova and also neutron adds compute hosts into the host aggregate based on how segments are mapped to hosts. Then nova mirrors the host aggregate to placement as placement aggregate.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/34cb6461be809e6ace42a57f2d71b5513ebcdf8d/neutron/services/segments/plugin.py#L281

There is an alternative where it is not nova who calls neutron to get the segments and then map them to aggregates but neutron provides the required aggregate relationship via port.resource_request attribute. This alternative has a neutron impact but in the other hand on the nova side it could reuse the existing port.resource_request handling added during the min bandwidth support feature.

This paragraph is easier to understand after reading the routed networks Neutron doc [1] (which should be listed as a reference here).

To rephrase what Sylvain is saying, booting with a port in a network segment works just fine, as long as no IP is specified, which lets Neutron pick an IP from the segment's subnet. Problems arise if an IP *is* specified, as Nova has no way of knowing which compute host(s) are hooked up to segments (subnets, to be more precise) that can actually provide that IP.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-routed-networks.html

you dont actully boot a vm with a port in a network segment
you boot a vm with a port attached to a network that has segments.

the way this works is when you create a network, it can be a routed network or standard, that is determined by if you create network segment and associate subnets to those segment or if you just create subnets.

when a network has segments the default ip_allocaton policy will be defer instead of intimidate. when the defer policy is in use
the ip address of the port is only assigned when the port is bound to a host. so when nova binds the port neutron uses that host to look up the segment(s) associcated with the host and network then it selects an ip from a corresponding subnet.

the issue is that once the ip is assigned once it will not change. so for move operation we have to keep the vm within the same segment that correspond to the ip's subnet otherwise teh port binding could fail and more importantly the ip will not be routable.

even though neutron models segments in placment via nova host aggreates nova is not aware of this and does not confine the host to members of that aggreate.

not there is a second problem with inital boot and rescduleds namely that once we bind the port the first time the segment will be selected and the ip assgined. if we retry the alternate hosts will not take that into account.

there is a third issue too whichs is realted. since we dont take into account ip avaiableiyt the first host we select might be in a segment that nolonger has ips aviable. ipv4 adress are actully modeled as an inventory in placment for routed network but we currently dont claim them.

finally if you create a port with a fixed ip instead of letting neutron assign it, which is still valid to do in a routed network deployment we also do not use its segment to filter the inital host list.

this would require a new segment/ip aware weigher
the spec does not currently address this so i would remove this personally as the spec as written does not enable this.
node
neutron is actully ment to do this automatically apparently but im not sure when it started doing that. i belive when ip_allocation was first added it was manually set.

IOW Neutron hits the [1] API, right? And this is already the case (I'm confirming because it's in the proposed change section, but based on the Neutron doc it's actually existing behavior)

 self.p_client.associate_aggregates(segment_id, [aggregate_uuid])

'openstack resource provider list', 'openstack aggregate list', and 'openstack resource provider aggregate list' would probably be the ones we get. It just helps provide context that you otherwise need to go spelunking through code and multiple docs for
I can surely add some details in a FUP if you wish, even if that means copying the existing neutron docs.

this function is pretty simple as the name of the host aggreate will be 
     SEGMENT_NAME_STUB % segment_id
which is 
    'Neutron segment id %s' % segment_id

so we just get the aggrate with that name then its uuid is the placemnt uuid.

so this can be done fiarly efficnetly as a db query with a list of aggrate names generated by looping over the segments

oslo_log/formatters.py.message: pep8: E266 too many leading '#' for block comment
pep8: F841 local variable 'e' is assigned to but never used

I wondering if this import shouldn't be with other imports at the beginning of this file.

Even if CI|pep8|hacking seems happy with that I think it break the H306 rule [1].

IIRC I don't seen imports in the middle of the code in oslo's projects.

So, please move this import with the others.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/latest/user/hacking.html#imports
The point is that importing uwsgi fails when running as standalone daemon - i.e. this is actually the check if the code is executed via uwsgi.

`opt` isn't a dict?

If yes it could be rewritten like this:

```
self.uwsgi_name = uwsgi.opt.get("name")
```

It will avoid the try/except section, Indeed, Python dictionary method get() returns a value for the given key. If key is not available then returns default value None. So you don't have to except something.

I suppose you looking for a `KeyError` exception, I think that except for `Exception` is a bit too much, and KeyError could be more appropriate here.

Else which exception are you expect to happen here?

> Well, in my opinion it's more intuitive to setting the
 > self.uwsgi_name to None in except block since it clearly says that
 > if any error occurs when getting the value it's set to None. When
 > not running under uwsgi this variable is meaningless so from
 > semantic point of view stating default value before would be
 > confusing.

Ok, then lets init the default here.

 > 
 > Putting log.debug (or better log.exception) would be definitely
 > nice - however - it's oslo.log and this code is executed before
 > (more precisely during) initialization of logging module thus its
 > not possible. That's the main point of not wanting to invoke any
 > error here.

Ok I seen.

No, I am not looking for KeyError - the most probable error to catch is ImportError. From my point of view it's much better to use broad exception clause here because it's pretty much ok to not have the uwsgi_name key in log events rather than having failed daemon due to any error (e.g. change in uwsgi options file) and since it's oslo.log user will not be informed because log system is not initialized at this point.

Well, in my opinion it's more intuitive to setting the self.uwsgi_name to None in except block since it clearly says that if any error occurs when getting the value it's set to None. When not running under uwsgi this variable is meaningless so from semantic point of view stating default value before would be confusing.

Putting log.debug (or better log.exception) would be definitely nice - however - it's oslo.log and this code is executed before (more precisely during) initialization of logging module thus its not possible. That's the main point of not wanting to invoke any error here.

Thanks for the given details, then I think it could be worth to add a comment to highlight this point.

Also what do you think about init `self.uwsgi_name = None` by default before the `try/except` to be sure to retrieve it all the time and add a log.debug under the `except` statement with the catched error to help us during debug session, it could help us to identify the kind of error we faced.

distributedcloud/dcmanager/manager/subcl.message: In the case where openstack is not installed in the central cloud, I don't think we should be querying the applications in each subcloud.
Right, and I saw you fix this in green thread changes.
Will correct in the coming patch.
It is dangerous to modify this file in place - can we regenerate it from scratch each time?
Unfortunately no, since the existing entries for other subclouds are not stored anywhere. We could re-generate this file with all the existing ones stored in dcmanager db in the future.

Retrieving the overrides several times is going to be expensive. Do the endpoints contain anything that could be modified by the user? If not, could we derive the endpoint names from data that is already available?

The sysinv get_overrides() call is for each of the services, so have to call it multiple times to get overrides for all the services. By getting fqdn overrides first serves another purpose, it wouldn't add subcloud endpoints that are not overridden (for DC to work on subcloud, its endpoints must overridden in order for system controller to access them).

doc/source/ideas/voting-procedure.rst.message: I think these are just placeholder that should be removed?

TBH I don't actually agree with this. Almost nothing important in OpenStack is decided by voting. Most decisions are made by consensus, and that's the way it should be. We haven't even held a contested election in nearly a year.

Note that on a couple of occasions we tried back-testing the results against a proportional Condorcet vote, and the results were either unchanged or benefitted only vendors whose staff tended to block-vote for a candidate.
(Example: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-November/050432.html)

It's pretty well established that a 2-round system is strictly worse than Condorcet, and only still exists in real life due to logistical limitations that don't apply to us. As such, I'm not really clear on why we need to consider it?
For other readers, I think this refers to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majority_judgment (which does not satisfy the Condorcet criterion).
Would be good to call out some examples of what these are. Even though you say they are well known, I'm not sure what you are referring to.

FYI the current procedure has been specified down to a painful level of detail (e.g. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Governance/TieBreaking). I wouldn't assume that these things haven't been considered.

ironic_lib/auth_basic.py.message:
This log level may be consistent with how Ironic generally does logging (in which case, ignore this comment), but:

OpenStack logging standards (https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-specs/specs/log-guidelines.html#definition-of-log-levels) say that ERROR-level logs mean page the operator in the middle of the night.

On one hand, Ironic is an admin-only API, so any failure to authenticate is actually a configuration error.

On the other hand, if the API is accessible (presumably the reason for authentication in the first place) then any random actor can generate ERROR-level log messages (and thus potentially pager beeps) at will.
Fair call. I think it's fine to change all this to INFO except for the one about the broken file.

setup.cfg.message: Clark, this should work regarding pinning - don't you think?

No, it is my understanding that for this to work properly you need a fairly up to date pip and setuptools. This also relies on metadata on pypi package indexes, but we set that metadata properly so not concerned about that aspect.

Specifically pbr gets installed as a setup_requires dependency. These dependencies are pulled down by easy install (which as far as I know does not support filtering by python requires). This means you'll get the latest pbr on python2 via easy install, then setuptools may be sad because it noticed the python-requires prevents it from working or it won't notice at all and try to run the python3 lib under python2.

PBR has specifically been a place where we've needed to be conservative to account for the fact that not everything is running an up to date python and friends installation. If we are super concerned about python2 support in PBR my hunch is that you may need to split the package name on pypi to avoid problems.

specs/victoria/approved/time-series-fram.message: Are you sure the datasources such as gnocchi can get a time series?

There is effectively no new datasource the only thing that changes is that instead of always retrieving one value from ceilometer, gnocchi, grafana etc: a list of values can be retrieved. I will update the spec to reflect how this new method could look.

Gnocchi is an interesting case as it stores time-series in a condensed aggregated format. I suspect this won't necessarily be a problem but it will likely mean Gnocchi its granularity will be worse compared to other time-series datasources.

For example the openstack cli supports `metric measures aggregation` which returns measurementS of aggregated values. 
https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/plugin-commands/gnocchi.html#metric-measures-aggregation
so maybe you want to add new datasource?
Is it a common class used for all ML strategies?

No not many Machine Learning algorithms use time-series analysis. It is more commonly used in statistically methods such as simple linear or polynomial regression. Many of the algorithms used to support machine learning algorithms are actually from completely different fields such as signal processing or statistics. 

Typically these algorithms are only employed to extract features from the data or reduce noise but they should not be considered Machine Learning in itself. Which supporting algorithms are employed and which features are extracted entirely depends on the problem that is attempted to be solved.

An example were a time-series decomposition would be a great addition to the dataset used by a ML algorithm would be in weather prediction. As to predict the weather any seasonal change in temperature could essentially be noise in the prediction based on local deviations in the average temperature (residual).

Previously we discussed that actual ML strategies for Watcher would be best developed as external component.
Yet, I would still like to use time series decomposition for potential new strategies, these new strategies will not use ML only the time series decomposition. But, perhaps it is better to focus on developing these strategies in an external component so that we can keep the libraries for Watcher itself small.
From my understanding,  there are a lot of mature third-party software can use to process data and extract features, ML strategies can use these features directly, perhaps this is better because.
is there any consideration of environment resources utilization by bulk data metrics during collection/processing?

Primarily by audit templates, these allows to define a scope which limits the number of availability_zones and host_aggregates. Naturally this significantly reduces the number of nodes and instances (assuming compute datamodel) resulting in less memory consumption.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: We delete the new attachments on the destination here...
And set the bdms to the old (source) attachments here.
I mean this is pure hax, and at some point we'll have to untangle all of this pre-post-over-under-super-hyper-live-migration stuff, but in the interest of fixing this and backporting the fix, OK.
And here. And we delete the attachments again, except by this time they're the source ones.
Gah! Thanks, I'll remove in a respin.

Having a look through the code so I understand:

Attachments rolled back on the dest and re-raised here during a pre_live_migration fail:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2f3a380c3c081fb022c8a2dcfdcc365733161cac/nova/compute/manager.py#L7833-L7845

Then we catch the re-raised exception on the source and call _cleanup_pre_live_migration:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2f3a380c3c081fb022c8a2dcfdcc365733161cac/nova/compute/manager.py#L8023-L8029

Which calls _rollback_live_migration:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2f3a380c3c081fb022c8a2dcfdcc365733161cac/nova/compute/manager.py#L7911-L7913

Which calls _rollback_volume_bdms:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2f3a380c3c081fb022c8a2dcfdcc365733161cac/nova/compute/manager.py#L8706

and that's where this logic comes in to make sure we don't delete the attachments if they are the originals.

Makes sense, nice and simple change.

releasenotes/notes/vxflexos-powerflex-re.message: Looks like the tabs and extra spaces in the release note are causing issues in the release notes job.

This should be updated to use the present tense, because by the time operators read this, the above will have happened.  I suggest something like:

Dell EMC VxFlex OS has been rebranded to PowerFlex. The driver
``cinder.volume.drivers.dell_emc.vxflexos.driver.VxFlexOSDriver``
has been renamed to
``cinder.volume.drivers.dell_emc.powerflex.driver.PowerFlexDriver``.
Although in this release the volume manager will recognize the old
driver name, that functionality will be removed in the Wallaby
release, and thus we recommend that you update the driver name in
``cinder.conf`` at your earliest convenience.

Existing vxFlex OS configuration options will continue to work in this
release, but this functionality will be removed in the Wallaby release.
Thus all driver configuration options that start with ``vxflexos``
should be updated to ``powerflex`` in your ``cinder.conf`` as soon
as possible.

Before the Rocky release, this driver was named
``cinder.volume.drivers.dell_emc.scaleio.driver.ScaleIODriver``.
That name was deprecated in the Rocky release.  In this release,
the pre-Rocky name for this driver is no longer recognized and
support for configuration options beginning with ``sio`` has been
removed.

The online documentation has been updated to reflect these changes.
